tinytim package#

Submodules#

tinytim.columns module#

tinytim.columns.column_dict(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], col: str) → Dict[str, Sequence]#

Return a dict of {col_name, col_values} from data.

Parameters:

  • data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • col (str) – column name to pull out of data.

Returns:

{column_name: column_values}

Return type:

dict[str, Sequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> column_dict(data, 'x')
{'x': [1, 2, 3]}
>>> column_dict(data, 'y')
{'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.columns.itercolumns(data: Mapping[str, Sequence]) → Generator[Tuple[str, tuple], None, None]#

Return a generator of tuple column name, column values.

Parameters:

data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

Returns:

generator that yields tuples(column_name, column_values)

Return type:

Generator[Tuple[str, tuple], None, None]

Example

>>> data = 'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> cols = list(itercolumns(data))
>>> cols[0]
('x', (1, 2, 3))
>>> cols[1]
('y', (6, 7, 8))
tinytim.columns.value_counts(values: Iterable, sort=True, ascending=True) → DictAnyKey#

Count up each value. Return a DictAnyKey[value] -> count Allows for unhashable values.

Parameters:

  • values – values to be counted up

  • sort (default True, sort results by counts) –

  • ascending (default True, sort highest to lowest) –

Returns:

{value: value_count}

Return type:

DictAnyKey[Any, int]

Example

>>> values = [4, 1, 1, 4, 5, 1]
>>> value_counts(values)
DictAnyKey((1, 3), (4, 2), (5, 1))

tinytim.copy module#

tinytim.copy.copy_list(values: List) → List#

Copy list and return the copy.

Parameters:

values (list) – list of values

Returns:

copy of list

Return type:

list

Example

>>> values = [1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]
>>> values_copy = copy_list(values)
>>> values_copy
[1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]
>>> values_copy[0] = 11
>>> values_copy
[11, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]
>>> values
[1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]
tinytim.copy.copy_table(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) → MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]#

Copy data and return the copy.

Parameters:

data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

Returns:

copy of data

Return type:

MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> copy_table(data)
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.copy.deepcopy_list(values: List) → List#

Deep copy list and return the copy.

Parameters:

values (list) – list of values

Returns:

deep copy of list

Return type:

list

Example

>>> values = [1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]
>>> values_copy = deepcopy_list(values)
>>> values_copy
[1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]
>>> values_copy[0] = 11
>>> values_copy
[11, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]
>>> values
[1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]
tinytim.copy.deepcopy_table(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) → dict#

Deep copy data and return the copy.

Parameters:

data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

Returns:

copy of data

Return type:

MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> deepcopy_table(data)
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}

tinytim.data module#

tinytim.data.column_count(data: Mapping[str, Sequence]) → int#

Return the number of columns in data.

Parameters:

data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

Returns:

number of columns in data

Return type:

int

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> column_count(data)
2
tinytim.data.column_names(data: Mapping[str, Sequence]) → Tuple[str]#

Parameters:

Returns:

Return type:

tuple[str]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> column_names(data)
('x', 'y')
tinytim.data.column_values(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], column_name: str) → Sequence#

Return all the values from one column.

Parameters:

  • data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • column_name (str) – name of column

Returns:

column values

Return type:

Sequence

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> column_values(data, 'y')
[6, 7, 8]
tinytim.data.first_column_name(data: Mapping[str, Sequence]) → str#

Return the name of the first column. Raises StopIteration if data has zero columns.

Parameters:

data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

Returns:

name of first column

Return type:

str

Raises:

StopIteration – if data has zero columns

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> first_column_name(data)
'x'
tinytim.data.head(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], n: int = 5) → Dict[str, Sequence]#

Return the first n rows of data.

Parameters:

  • data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • n (int, optional) – number of rows to return from top of data

Returns:

{column name: top n column values}

Return type:

dict[str, Sequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> head(data, 2)
{'x': [1, 2], 'y': [6, 7]}

Return type:

tuple[int]

Example

>>> index(data)
(0, 1, 2)

tinytim.data.shape(data: Mapping[str, Sequence]) → Tuple[int, int]#

Returns:

(row count, column count)

Return type:

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> shape(data)
(3, 2)

Parameters:

data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

Returns:

row count * column count

Return type:

int

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> size(data)
6
tinytim.data.table_value(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], column_name: str, index: int) → Any#

Return one value from column at row index.

Parameters:

  • data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • column_name (str) – name of column

  • index (int) – index of column value

Returns:

value of column at index

Return type:

Any

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> table_value(data, 'x', 1)
2
tinytim.data.tail(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], n: int = 5) → Dict[str, Sequence]#

Return the last n rows of data.

Parameters:

  • data (Mapping[str, Sequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • n (int, optional) – number of rows to return from bottom of data

Returns:

{column name: bottom n column values}

Return type:

dict

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> tail(data, 2)
{'x': [2, 3], 'y': [7, 8]}

tinytim.edit module#

tinytim.edit.drop_column(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], column_name: str) → MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]#

Return a new dict with the named column removed from data.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • column_name (str) – name of column to remove from data

Returns:

copy of data with column dropped

Return type:

MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> drop_column(data, 'y')
{'x': [1, 2, 3]}
>>> data
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.edit.drop_column_inplace(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], column_name: str) → None#

Remove named column from data.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • column_name (str) – name of column to remove from data

Return type:

None

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> drop_column_inplace(data, 'y')
>>> data
{'x': [1, 2, 3]}
tinytim.edit.drop_label(labels: Union[None, List], index: int) → Union[None, List]#

If labels exists, drop item at index.

Parameters:

  • labels (list, optional) – list of values used as labels

  • index (int) – index of value to remove from labels list

Returns:

copy of labels with row dropped

Return type:

list | None

Examples

>>> labels = [1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> drop_label(labels, 1)
[1, 3, 4]
>>> labels
[1, 3, 4, 5]

>>> labels = None
>>> drop_label(labels, 1)
None
>>> labels
None
tinytim.edit.drop_label_inplace(labels: Union[None, List], index) → None#

If labels exists, drop item at index.

Parameters:

  • labels (list, optional) – list of values used as labels

  • index (int) – index of value to remove from labels list

Return type:

None

Examples

>>> labels = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
>>> drop_label_inplace(labels, 1)
>>> labels
[1, 3, 4, 5]

>>> labels = None
>>> drop_label_inplace(labels, 1)
>>> labels
None
tinytim.edit.drop_row(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], index: int) → MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]#

Return a new dict with index row removed from data.

Example: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} drop_row(data, 0) -> {‘x’: [2, 3], ‘y’: [7, 8]} data -> {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]}

tinytim.edit.drop_row_inplace(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], index: int) → None#

Remove index row from data.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • index (int) – index of row to remove from data

Return type:

None

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> drop_row_inplace(data, 1)
>>> data
{'x': [1, 3], 'y': [6, 8]}
tinytim.edit.edit_column(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], column_name: str, values: MutableSequence) → MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]#

Returns a new dict with values added to data in named column. Overrides existing values if column exists, Created new column with values if column does not exist.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • column_name (str) – column name to edit in data

  • values (Sequence) – new values to replace in data column

Returns:

copy of data with new column values

Return type:

MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_column(data, 'x', [4, 5, 6])
{'x': [4, 5, 6], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> data
 {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.edit.edit_column_inplace(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], column_name: str, values: MutableSequence) → None#

Add values to data in named column. Overrides existing values if column exists, Created new column with values if column does not exist.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • column_name (str) – column name to edit in data

  • values (Sequence) – new values to replace in data column

Return type:

None

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_column_inplace(data, 'x', [11, 22, 33])
>>> data
{'x': [11, 22, 33], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.edit.edit_row_items(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], index: int, items: Mapping) → MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]#

Return a new dict with row index changed to mapping items values.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • index (int) – index of row to edit

  • items (Mapping[str, Any]) – {column names: value} of new values to edit in data

Returns:

copy of data with edited row values

Return type:

MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]

Examples

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_row_items(data, 2, {'x': 33, 'y': 88})
{'x': [1, 2, 33], 'y': [6, 7, 88]}
>>> data
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_row_items(data, 0, {'x': 55})
{'x': [55, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> data
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.edit.edit_row_items_inplace(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], index: int, items: Mapping[str, Any]) → None#

Changes row index to mapping items values.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • index (int) – index of row to edit

  • items (Mapping[str, Any]) – {column names: value} of new values to edit in data

Return type:

None

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_row_items_inplace(data, 0, {'x': 11, 'y': 66})
>>> data
{'x': [11, 2, 3], 'y': [66, 7, 8]}
tinytim.edit.edit_row_values(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], index: int, values: Sequence) → MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]#

Return a new dict with row index changed to values.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • index (int) – index of row to edit

  • values (Sequence) – new values to replace in data row

Returns:

copy of data with row at index changed to values

Return type:

MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_row_values(data, 1, (22, 77))
{'x': [1, 22, 3], 'y': [6, 77, 8]}
>>> data
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.edit.edit_row_values_inplace(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], index: int, values: Sequence) → None#

Changed row index to values.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • index (int) – index of row to edit

  • values (Sequence) – new values to replace in data row

Return type:

None

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_row_values_inplace(data, 1, (22, 77))
>>> data
{'x': [1, 22, 3], 'y': [6, 77, 8]}
tinytim.edit.edit_value(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], column_name: str, index: int, value: Any) → MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]#

Return a new table with the value in named column changed at row index.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • column_name (str) – name of column to remove from data

  • index (int) – row index of column to edit

  • value (Any) – new value to change to

Returns:

copy of data with new value changed

Return type:

MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_value(data, 'y', 2, 88)
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 88]}
>>> data
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.edit.edit_value_inplace(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], column_name: str, index: int, value: Any) → None#

Edit the value in named column as row index.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • column_name (str) – name of column to remove from data

  • index (int) – row index of column to edit

  • value (Any) – new value to change to

Return type:

None

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> edit_value_inplace(data, 'x', 0, 11)
>>> data
{'x': [11, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
tinytim.edit.replace_column_names(data: MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence], new_names: Sequence[str]) → Dict[str, MutableSequence]#

Return a new dict same column data but new column names.

Parameters:

  • data (MutableMapping[str, MutableSequence]) – data mapping of {column name: column values}

  • new_names (Sequence[str]) – new names of columns

Returns:

copy of data with new column names

Return type:

Dict[str, MutableSequence]

Example

>>> data = {'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> replace_column_names(data, ('xx', 'yy'))
>>> {'xx': [1, 2, 3], 'yy': [6, 7, 8]}
>>> data
{'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [6, 7, 8]}

Return only rows of data where named column is greater than value.

Return only rows of data where named column is in values.

tinytim.filter.filter_by_column_le(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], column_name: str, value) → Dict[str, Sequence]#

Return only rows of data where named column is less than or equal value.

Return only rows of data where named column is less than value.

Return only rows of data where named column does not equal value.

tinytim.filter.filter_by_column_notin(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], column_name: str, values: Sequence) → Dict[str, Sequence]#

tinytim.json module#

Module used for converting data format to json and json to data format.

tinytim.json.data_to_json(data: Mapping[str, Sequence]) → str#

Example: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} data_to_json(data) -> ‘’’[{“x”: 1, “y”: 6},

{“x”: 2, “y”: 7}, {“x”: 3, “y”: 8}]’’’

tinytim.json.data_to_json_list(data: Mapping[str, Sequence]) → List[Dict]#

Example: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} data_to_json_list(data) -> [{‘x’: 1, ‘y’: 6},

{‘x’: 2, ‘y’: 7}, {‘x’: 3, ‘y’: 8}]

tinytim.json.json_list_to_data(l: List[Dict]) → Dict[str, list]#

Example: json = [{‘x’: 1, ‘y’: 6},

{‘x’: 2, ‘y’: 7}, {‘x’: 3, ‘y’: 8}]

json_list_to_data(json) -> {‘x’: [1, 2, 3],

‘y’: [6, 7, 8]}

tinytim.json.json_to_data(j: str) → Dict[str, list]#

Example: j = ‘’’[{“x”: 1, “y”: 6},

{“x”: 2, “y”: 7}, {“x”: 3, “y”: 8}]’’’

json_to_data(j) -> {‘x’: [1, 2, 3],

‘y’: [6, 7, 8]}

tinytim.rows module#

tinytim.rows.iterrows(data: Mapping) → Generator[Tuple[int, dict], None, None]#

Return a generator of tuple row index, row dict values.

Examples: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} generator = iterrows(data) next(generator) -> (0, {‘x’: 1, ‘y’: 6}) next(generator) -> (1, {‘x’: 2, ‘y’: 7}) next(generator) -> (2, {‘x’: 3, ‘y’: 8}) next(generator) -> StopIteration

tinytim.rows.itertuples(data: Mapping) → Generator[tuple, None, None]#

Return a generator of tuple row values.

Examples: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} generator = itertuples(data) next(generator) -> (1, 6) next(generator) -> (2, 7) next(generator) -> (3, 8) next(generator) -> StopIteration

tinytim.rows.itervalues(data: MutableMapping) → Generator[tuple, None, None]#

Return a generator of tuple row values.

Examples: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} generator = itertuples(data) next(generator) -> (1, 6) next(generator) -> (2, 7) next(generator) -> (3, 8) next(generator) -> StopIteration

tinytim.rows.row_dict(data: Mapping, index: int) → dict#

Return one row from data at index.

Examples: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} row_dict(data, 1) -> {‘x’: 2, ‘y’: 7}

tinytim.rows.row_value_counts(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], sort=True, ascending=True) → Dict[tuple, int]#

Count up the unique rows. Return dict[(row_values)] -> count

Example: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 3, 3]} row_value_counts(data) -> {(3, 3): 2,

(1, 6): 1, (2, 7): 1}

tinytim.rows.row_values(data: MutableMapping, index: int) → tuple#

Return a tuple of the values at row index.

Examples: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} row_values(data, 0) -> (1, 6)

tinytim.rows.values(data: MutableMapping) → Tuple[tuple]#

Return tuple of tuple row values.

Examples: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8]} values(data) -> ((1, 6), (2, 7), (3, 8))

tinytim.utils module#

tinytim.utils.all_bool(values: Collection) → bool#

Return if all items in values are bool or not.

Examples: values = [1, True, False, True] all_bool(values) -> False

values = [True, True, False, True] all_bool(values) -> True

tinytim.utils.all_keys(dicts: Sequence[Mapping]) → List#

Return all the unique keys from a collection of dicts.

Examples: dicts = [{‘x’: 1, ‘y’: 2}, {‘x’: 4, ‘z’: 7}] all_keys(dicts) -> [‘x’, ‘y’, ‘z’]

tinytim.utils.combine_names_rows(column_names: Sequence[str], rows: Sequence[Sequence]) → Dict[str, List]#

Convert a sequence of column names and a sequence of row values into dict[column_name: values] format.

Examples: column_names = [‘x’, ‘y’] rows = ((1, 2), (4, 5), (8, 10)) combine_names_rows(column_names, rows) -> {‘x’: [1, 4, 8], ‘y’: [2, 5, 10]}

tinytim.utils.has_mapping_attrs(obj: Any) → bool#

Check if object has all Mapping attrs.

Examples: obj = dict() has_mapping_attrs(obj) -> True

obj = list() has_mapping_attrs(obj) -> False

tinytim.utils.nunique(data: Mapping[str, Sequence]) → Dict[str, int]#

Count number of distinct values in each column. Return dict with number of distinct values.

Examples: data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 2], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8], ‘z’: [9, 9, 9]} nunique(data) -> {‘x’: 2, ‘y’: 3, ‘z’: 1}

tinytim.utils.nuniques(values: Sequence) → int#
tinytim.utils.row_dicts_to_data(rows: Sequence[Mapping[str, Any]], missing_value: Optional[Any] = None) → Dict[str, list]#

Convert a list of row dicts to dict[col_name: values] format.

Examples: rows = [{‘x’: 1, ‘y’: 20}, {‘x’: 2, ‘y’: 21}, {‘x’: 3, ‘y’: 22}] row_dicts_to_data(rows) -> {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [20, 21, 22]}

rows = [{‘x’: 1, ‘y’: 20}, {‘x’: 2}, {‘x’: 3, ‘y’: 22}] row_dicts_to_data(rows) -> {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [20, None, 22]}

tinytim.utils.row_value_tuples(data: Mapping[str, Sequence], column_names: Sequence[str]) → Tuple[tuple]#

Return row value tuples for only columns in column_names.

data = {‘x’: [1, 2, 3], ‘y’: [6, 7, 8], ‘z’: [9, 10, 11]} row_value_tuples(data, [‘x’, ‘z’]) -> ((1, 9), (2, 10), (3, 11))

tinytim.utils.row_values_generator(row: Mapping[str, Any]) → Generator[Any, None, None]#

Return a generator that yields values from a row dict.

Examples: row = {‘x’: 1, ‘y’: 4, ‘z’: 8} generator = row_values_generator(row) next(generator) -> 1 next(generator) -> 4 next(generator) -> 8 next(generator) -> StopIteration

tinytim.utils.slice_to_range(s: slice, stop: Optional[int] = None) → range#

Convert an int:int:int slice object to a range object. Needs stop if s.stop is None since range is not allowed to have stop=None.

Examples: s = slice(1, 4, 0) slice_to_range(s) -> ValueError

s = slice(0, 3, 1) slice_to_range(s) -> range(0, 3, 1)

tinytim.utils.uniques(values: Iterable) → List#

Return a list of the unique items in values.

Examples: values = [1, 1, 2, 4, 5, 2, 0, 6, 1] uniques(values) -> [1, 2, 4, 5, 0, 6]

tinytim.validate module#

tinytim.validate.data_columns_same_len(data: MutableMapping) → bool#

Check if data columns are all the same len.

tinytim.validate.valid_table_mapping(data: MutableMapping) → bool#

Check if data is a true TableMapping.
